</div>

Is there any reason why the `XYZCommandParser.parse()` functions are implemented as class functions rather than a static function? What is the advantage of 

'''java
        case AddCommand.COMMAND_WORD:
            return new AddCommandParser().parse(arguments);

        case EditCommand.COMMAND_WORD:
            return new EditCommandParser().parse(arguments);

        case DeleteCommand.COMMAND_WORD:
            return new DeleteCommandParser().parse(arguments);
'''

over

'''java
        case AddCommand.COMMAND_WORD:
            return new AddCommandParser.parse(arguments);

        case EditCommand.COMMAND_WORD:
            return new EditCommandParser.parse(arguments);

        case DeleteCommand.COMMAND_WORD:
            return new DeleteCommandParser.parse(arguments);
'''

package seedu.address.logic.commands;

public class RemarkCommandTest ``{``

**50. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡`runtest.sh` copies `EXPECTED.txt` into `EXPECTED-UNIX.txt`**
</div>

I wanted to double check that my `runtest.sh` script was correctly able to detect differences by editing `EXPECTED-UNIX.txt`, and was confused why it kept overwriting `EXPECTED-UNIX.txt` with the original text and pass the test run.

I tried reading through the code then realised that it still uses `EXPECTED.txt` instead, and just copies it, as can be seen in this part below
'''sh
# convert to UNIX format
cp EXPECTED.TXT EXPECTED-UNIX.TXT
dos2unix ACTUAL.TXT EXPECTED-UNIX.TXT
'''

So only editing `EXPECTED.txt` is necessary.

Thanks Prof @damithc for that info. I found a work around using that by doing the following
- Rename local `branch-A-Javadoc` to `branch-A-JavaDoc2` then back to `branch-A-JavaDoc`
- Rename branch on GitHub from `branch-A-Javadoc` to `branch-A-JavaDoc2`
- Fetch all branches on SourceTree
- Delete `origin/branch-A-Javadoc` from SourceTree
- Rename branch on GitHub from `branch-A-JavaDoc2` to `branch-A-JavaDoc`
- Fetch all branches on SourceTree
- Delete `origin/branch-A-JavaDoc2` from SourceTree
- Set the local branch `branch-A-JavaDoc` to track `origin/branch-A-JavaDoc` instead of `origin/branch-A-Javadoc`
</panel>

I think you could argue that using "as a" here is still fine. "A" and "an" are allomorphs of the same morpheme in English, with "a" being the underlying representation and "an" only being used before vowel sounds. The context of the header should be independent of the rows (since you can have multiple rows, some of which use "a" while others use "an"), so the base form "a" would get used instead.

To add onto this since the issue isn't closed yet, inside the implementation of your `equals()` method, you should also use the `equals()` method itself. So something like
'''java
public bool equals(Object o) ``{``
    if (o == null) ``{`` return false; ``}``
    if (!(o instanceof Class)) ``{`` return false; ``}``
    Class o_ = (Class) o;
    return (a == o._a) && (b == o_.b);
'''
might result in a bug since `a == o_.a` checks if the exact same instance of `a` is being used. Using 
'''java
public bool equals(Object o) ``{``
    if (o == null) ``{`` return false; ``}``
    if (!(o instanceof Class)) ``{`` return false; ``}``
    Class o_ = (Class) o;
    return a.equals(o_.a) && b.equals(o_.b);
'''
would be safer
</panel>

**4. :fas-info-circle: What should the severity of the AB3 email bug be?**
</div>

If you continued using the Email class in your app without any modifications, then it's possible that a tester reported bug arising from this. The bug is that valid emails, at least according to the error message shown by it like `special+._-char@example.com` gets invalidated.

The restrictions for email provided (carried from AB3):
Emails should be of the format local-part@domain and adhere to the following constraints:

The local-part should only contain alphanumeric characters and these special characters, excluding the parentheses, (+_.-). The local-part may not start or end with any special characters.
This is followed by a '@' and then a domain name. The domain name is made up of domain labels separated by periods.
The domain name must:
end with a domain label at least 2 characters long
have each domain label start and end with alphanumeric characters
have each domain label consist of alphanumeric characters, separated only by hyphens, if any.

As such, `special+._-char@example.com` would be considered a valid email but it will get invalidated by any team's app that used the Email class without any modifications. This should be considered a `type.FunctionalityBug` but what severity should this bug get?
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S2/forum/issues/575" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**17. :fas-info-circle: [Discussion] Is SLAP really a good idea?**
</div>

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bdf19ab9-1c97-4bbf-85d0-f79976d3d712)

Under the section of Code Quality, we are told to avoid deep nesting as __its harder for the reader to keep track of the logic__. I agree with this and this is usually fixed with guard clauses.

However, we are then also told to follow SLAP where we should try to use the highest level of abstraction as much as possible as shown below.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/33e6ca53-d4a2-4033-b445-00b9262b8e2a)

My question is then doesn't this feel contradictory with the reasoning to avoid deep nesting as if the methods being called are scattered in many different classes, doesn't make it harder for the reader to keep track of the logic than if it were placed all in one method?

Personally, I understand that having a very long method is bad for readability but if it's not too long, should SLAP still be enforced because I feel that it makes it harder to keep track of the logic in doing so sometimes and may be harder when trying to debug than if it were placed all in one place.

Just wanted to know other people's views on this. 
</panel>

Seeing how many issues there are regarding SourceTree and how I also faced issues using it, I want to suggest an alternative to it that is, using the Git feature in IntelliJ itself. 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/943b1ae3-7dc8-4fef-b358-22d46d968516)

If you are not aware of it already, IntelliJ has this feature where you can do most of the things you need to do with git with a similar (and in my opinion more intuitive) way to SourceTree. This is how I did it:
'''java
/**
 * Displays the goodbye message when the program ends.
 */
@Override
public void sayBye() ``{``
    String response = "Bye. Hope to see you again soon!";
    showRoverResponse(response);
    new Timer().schedule(new TimerTask() ``{``
        public void run() ``{``
            Platform.exit();
        ``}``
    ``}``, 2000);
``}``
'''

This allows the application to say the goodbye message and then close after 2s.
I got it from [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21974415/how-to-close-this-javafx-application-after-showing-a-message-in-a-text-area-elem).

Hi Prof @damithc ,

After reviewing the PE-D issues raised by my peers regarding input validation, I would appreciate your guidance on several points that have caused some confusion.

The main areas I'd like clarification on are:

1. User Responsibility vs. Software Validation. 
    The point on "overzealous input validation" (considered a `type.FeatureFlaw`) was particularly confusing to me, as it meant that such relaxations allows for more invalid inputs. I have listed a few examples below.
   - For name inputs: Should we support international characters (e.g., "Ø¹ÙŽØ¨Ù’Ø¯Ù Ø§Ù„Ø±ÙŽÙ‘Ø­Ù’Ù…ÙŽÙ†"), even if it means relaxing validation (ie. potential invalid names)?
   - For faculty names: Should we allow single-character inputs, or implement stricter validation?
   - For phone numbers: Enforcement of a minimally 3 digits, although it is unexpected for people to possess such numbers?

2. Application Requirements
   - Regarding issue #544 (TLD of an email is technically not required, although highly encouraged).

3. User Guide Documentation
   - Should input constraints be explicitly documented, or should we maintain AB3's approach of handling issues within the application itself?

4. Unique Identifier Requirements
   - Should fields like name, phone number, and email be unique identifiers? Personally, I felt that there was no need to considering the fact that there may be cases of all happening. (i.e. two or more people may temporarily share the same contact in the event that their original form of contact is unavailable).

Thank you everyone for the suggestions. I think my phrasing was not sufficiently clear, and I have provided a revision below. 

Definitely following English definitions, an 'Event' as well as a 'DoWithinPeriodTask' have nuanced differences. However, in this context, such differences are (arguably) dubious.
For example, many have suggested that 'Event' tasks should be unmarkable for the entirety of its duration. Indeed, some events, such as conferences requires one's time to be blocked out for its entire duration. However, other events such as sales, exhibitions (and even some conferences) etc., will not require (and sometimes illogical) for one to attend for the entirety of its duration. This (to me) should still be an 'Event' instead of a 'Task' as attending the 'Event' itself may be completely optional, compared to the necessities of a 'Task'.

Moreover, the above example suggests that such nuanced differences are captured by additional features as well as functionalities that has to be implemented. This is not what is specifically required for a 'DoWithinPeriodTask', which states that it is merely a task that needs to be done within a certain period of time, ie. a 'startDate' as well as an 'endDate'. This is exactly the same as what the 'Event' class currently supports. Then at its core, this would essentially be a code duplication, with the only exception of the '[E]' tag that is used to demarcate the 'Event class.

Thus, is it fair for me to say that the creating a new 'DoWithinPeriodTask' class would effectively result in a duplication of the existing 'Event' classs functionality, with the exception of the '[E]' tag?
</panel>

            new Timer(true).schedule(new TimerTask() ``{``

                    Platform.exit();

            ``}``, 1000);
```

> [@minhkiwi14](https://github.com/minhkiwi14) If you committed to the master branch accidentally but have not pushed those commits to the team repo yet, the best remedy is to either, (a) delete those rogue commits, or, (b) move them to a branch, and follow the forking workflow to incorporate those commits properly into the team repo via a PR.
> 
> This way, you own master branch can remain identical to the team repo master branch, as it should.


> [@minhkiwi14](https://github.com/minhkiwi14) Setting `pull.rebase` to `false` is very similar to `git fetch upstream && git merge upstream/master`. I don't see any issues from that.
> 
> Personal tip to prevent data losses when you encounter merge conflicts like this: try to backup your local master branch using `git checkout -b backup-master`.
> 
> FYI, in other practices (not used in CS2103T because it might incur lost of timestamp), you can also `cherry-pick` the commits that you wish to apply onto the upstream master.

<div slot="header">

**14. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡Tip: Edit `checkstyle.xml` to suppress indentation warnings for lambda-style switch statements**
</div>

###### The original discussion on this topic can be found at #68. The solution is posted here as a tip to be captured in #117.

## Context

The [coding standard](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/intermediate.html#layout) allows for indented `case` blocks in lambda-style switch statements (but not for conventional switch statements). So the following is allowed:
'''java
int size = switch (condition) ``{``
    case ABC -&gt; 1;
    case DEF -&gt; 2;
    case XYZ -&gt; 3;
    default -&gt; 0;
``}``
'''
However, the [Checkstyle configuration](https://github.com/se-edu/addressbook-level3/tree/master/config/checkstyle) provided enforces a relative indentation level of 0 for all `case` blocks, including those in lambda-style switch statements. This results in false positive error messages when running Checkstyle.

## Solution

Insert the following at line 39 of `checkstyle.xml`:
'''xml
&lt;!-- Suppresses indentation check for lambda-style switch statements -->
&lt;module name="SuppressionXpathSingleFilter">
    &lt;property name="checks" value="Indentation"/>
    &lt;property name="query" value="//SWITCH_RULE/descendant-or-self::node()"/>
&lt;/module>
'''
This suppresses indentation checks for lambda-style switch statements (without suppressing checks for conventional switch statements).

> [!CAUTION]
> Within the lambda-style switch statement, _all_ indentation checks are suppressed (to our knowledge, there doesn't seem to be a way to suppress just the `caseIndent` rule). You should ensure that indentation within that block still follows the coding standard.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S2/forum/issues/120" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**15. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡Tip: Edit `SceneBuilder.cfg` to fix JavaFX version as 17**
</div>

I noticed that the [JavaFX tutorial (Part 4)](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/javaFxPart4.html) has this notice:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d265687b-c55a-43ea-9a9b-7ba0b9a64231)

This can be avoided by editing `SceneBuilder.cfg` to include the following line:
```
java-options=-Djavafx.version=17
```

Scene Builder will now keep the JavaFX version as 17, eliminating the need to manually correct the version number in the FXML file.

> [!NOTE]
> If you edit `SceneBuilder.cfg` while Scene Builder is open, these changes will not take effect until Scene Builder is restarted.

<details>
<summary>Locating <code>SceneBuilder.cfg</code> on Windows</summary>
<br/>

1. Locate Scene Builder's installation path. By default, this should be `C:/Users/``{``user``}``/AppData/Local/SceneBuilder`.
    - If you cannot find `AppData`, go to View > Show > Hidden Items in File Explorer, or Win+R and run `%localappdata%`.
    - If Scene Builder is installed somewhere else, you may locate it by finding it through the Start Menu and selecting "Open file location". If this opens a location with Scene Builder as a shortcut, right-click on it and select "Open file location" again.
2. Navigate to `app/` and `SceneBuilder.cfg` should be there.

</details>
</panel>

Hi, as part of `Level-8`, I've visited the [Gradle tutorial](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/gradle.html#running-checkstyle) which links to the [checkstyle tutorial](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/checkstyle.html#configuring-checkstyle), which suggests using the checkstyle configuration [here](https://github.com/se-edu/addressbook-level3/tree/master/config/checkstyle).

This configuration imposes a relative indentation level of 0 for all `case` statements (with the line `&lt;property name="caseIndent" value="0" />`). While this is consistent with [the coding standard](https://se-education.org/guides/conventions/java/intermediate.html#layout) for conventional `switch` statements, it does not take lambda-style `switch` statements into account. The coding standard allows lambda-style `switch` statements to have indented `case` blocks as follows:

> Lambda-style `switch` statements/expressions can have indented `case` blocks (as shown below):
> '''java
> switch (condition) ``{``
>     case ABC -&gt; method("1");
>     case DEF -&gt; method("2");
>     case XYZ -&gt; method("3");
>     default -&gt; method("0");
> ``}``
> '''
> '''java
> int size = switch (condition) ``{``
>     case ABC -&gt; 1;
>     case DEF -&gt; 2;
>     case XYZ -&gt; 3;
>     default -&gt; 0;
> ``}``
> '''

May I check if there is a way to modify `checkstyle.xml` such that it allows indented `case` blocks for lambda-style `switch` statements, while also imposing unindented `case` blocks for conventional `switch` statements?
</panel>

**27 :fas-comment:**
</div>

As per the [Java Language Specification, section 8.4.9](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se17/html/jls-8.html#jls-8.4.9):

> When a method is invoked (Â§15.12), the number of actual arguments (and any explicit type arguments) and the **compile-time types of the arguments** are used, at compile time, to determine the signature of the method that will be invoked (Â§15.12.2). If the method that is to be invoked is an instance method, the actual method to be invoked will be determined at run time, using dynamic method lookup (Â§15.12.4).

So you can't rely on polymorphism for method parameters, since the method call looks at the compile-time type of the arguments.

However, you could define an instance method `toStorageString` (if `toString` is already being used for something else) in `Todo` and override it in `Deadline` and `Event`, so that calling `toStorageString` on the object will call the relevant method based on its runtime-type.
</panel>

Thank you Prof. I tried to get the Checkstyle configuration to support lambda-style `switch` statements, but couldn't figure it out. I'm posting my approach here in case anyone else would like to attempt this (so that they don't waste too time much trying to do the same thing I did).

The closest I got was suppressing the `caseIndent` check for lines matching the regex `(case\s\S+|default)\s->`, but this couldn't be extended to lines within the `switch` statement that didn't have `case` or `default` . For example,

'''java
Task task = switch (type) ``{``
    case 'T' -&gt; new Todo(description); // works, suppresses correctly 
    case 'D' -&gt; ``{`` // works, suppresses correctly
        String dueBy = scanner.nextLine().trim(); // does not suppress since this line does not match the regex
        yield new Deadline(description, dueBy); // does not suppress
    ``}`` // does not suppress
    case 'E' -&gt; ``{`` // suppresses correctly
        String from = scanner.nextLine().trim(); // does not suppress
        String to = scanner.nextLine().trim(); // does not suppress
        yield new Event(description, from, to); // does not suppress
    ``}`` // does not suppress
    default -&gt; throw new InvalidFileFormatException(); // suppresses correctly
``}``;
'''
I used [SuppressWithNearbyTextFilter](https://checkstyle.org/filters/suppresswithnearbytextfilter.html) in my approach, and I think it's limited in that the regex it matches only checks line-by-line, so there isn't really a way to handle the case above.

For my iP, I'll likely suppress checkstyle for lambda-style `switch` statements. I'd like to leave this issue open for a while, in case anyone else has suggestions.
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S2/forum/issues/68#issuecomment-2618047723" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**30 :fas-comment:**
</div>

@kubrian I went down another rabbit hole, and after seeing [this fix](https://github.com/checkstyle/checkstyle/blob/master/src/main/resources/google_checks.xml#L294) used for a related issue, I seem to have come up with a solution. It still suppresses the whole `Indentation` module for the scope of the switch statement (not just `caseIndent`), but at least we don't have to manually ignore the checks via `// CHECKSTYLE.OFF/ON Indentation` now.

Add the following section in the `TreeWalker` module (so at around line 39 of `checkstyle.xml`):

'''xml
&lt;!-- Suppresses indentation check for lambda-style switch statements -->
&lt;module name="SuppressionXpathSingleFilter">
    &lt;property name="checks" value="Indentation"/>
    &lt;property name="query" value="//SWITCH_RULE/descendant-or-self::node()"/>
&lt;/module>
'''

This should suppress indentation checks for lambda-style `switch` statements. I have also verified that this (correctly) does not suppress indentation checks for conventional `switch` statements (since these use `CASE_GROUP` instead of `SWITCH_RULE` in the AST).
</panel>

> I thought I didn't need because ProgressWatcher implements Watcher, so the dependency is implicitly there in the form of a solid black line.
> If ProgressWatcher needs this dependency, why doesn't UiWidget need this dependency from Activity too?

ProgressWatcher implementing Watcher does not make Activity dependent on ProgressWatcher. the dependency exists because Activity references ProgressWatcher.MAX

if ProgressWatcher is deleted, Activity cannot compile (since ProgressWatcher.MAX is not defined), so Activity is dependent on ProgressWatcher. If UiWidget is deleted, Activity can still compile (Activity is not dependent on UiWidget)

</panel>

I personally feel that input validation is rather subjective and context-dependent. This is also mentioned in the bug triaging page:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/15d64c59-8db0-4620-a8bb-3736c6ee76d9)

For the supporting of international characters in point 1, it feels like a lose-lose situation, whereby you either allow it and get 'bug reports' that such non-ASCII characters are allowed. On the other hand, if you disallow it, you still get 'bug reports' that such names are considered valid but are not allowed. Hence, I believe that this jurisdiction is entirely up to the developer(s).

Phone numbers are also highly arguable. I noticed some bug reports complaining that they're allowed to intentionally enter an invalid phone number, and that it should be fixed by checking if it's 8 digits, and starts with either 6, 8 or 9. But, these 'professional' bug reporters simply assumed that the application would only be catered towards Singapore-numbers. So it's also valid to argue against their short-sightedness.

Unique identifies are also subjective as well, because like you mentioned, two or more people may temporarily share the same contact. But some people would still argue that these should be unique as well, submitting their 'bug reports' thinking that they're right. Again, it's up to how the developers want to affirm their stance on this.

</panel>

**9. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡ On using the bye command to close the GUI**
</div>

### Just a sharing on the closing of the GUI

when im trying to keep the bye command(when user input "bye", the application should print bye and close after that.
I tried to use `Platform.exit());` in this package `import javafx.application.Platform;`in my `ExitCommand.java` file

```
package lumi;

import javafx.animation.PauseTransition;
import javafx.application.Platform;
import javafx.util.Duration;

/**
 * Represents a command to exit the application.
 */
public class ExitCommand extends Command ``{``
    @Override

    /*
     * Executes the exit command by saving tasks and displaying a goodbye message.
     *
     * @param tasks The task list to save before exiting.
     * @param ui The UI instance for displaying the goodbye message.
     * @param storage The storage instance to save tasks.
     * @throws LumiException If an error occurs while saving tasks.
     */
    public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) throws LumiException ``{``
        storage.saveTasks(tasks.getTasks());
        ui.showGoodbye();
        Platform.exit());
    ``}``

    /**
     * Indicates that this command signals program termination.
     *
     * @return ``{``@code true``}``, as this command exits the application.
     */
    @Override
    public boolean isExit() ``{``
        return true;
    ``}``
``}``

```
and I realise this indeed close the application but it will close immediately without showing my `ui.showGoodbye();`
I supposed that the problem is because this command close the window immediately after `ui.showGoodbye()`executed , 
so I tried to delay the execution of the exit by doing` Thread.sleep(100)`

```
    Platform.runLater(() -&gt; ``{``
            try ``{``
                Thread.sleep(500); // Wait 500ms before closing (adjust if needed)
            ``}`` catch (InterruptedException e) ``{``
                Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
            ``}``
            Platform.exit(); // Close JavaFX application after UI update
        ``}``);
```

**but I noticed that this will block the thread for the whole block of code including the ui command.
there is different way that is putting two different threads, one is to handle the ui command , other one handles the exit.

just wang to share another way I find that can delay the exit command 
through PauseTransition**


import javafx.animation.PauseTransition;
import javafx.util.Duration;

PauseTransition delay = new PauseTransition(Duration.seconds(1));
    delay.setOnFinished(event -&gt; Platform.exit());
    delay.play();

open for a while if anyone has other way to implement.**

            + "Example: " + COMMAND_WORD + " 1 "
            + "r/ Likes to swim.";

    public static final String MESSAGE_ARGUMENTS = "Index: %1$d, Remark: %2$s";
    public static final String MESSAGE_ADD_REMARK_SUCCESS = "Added remark to Person: %1$s";
    public static final String MESSAGE_DELETE_REMARK_SUCCESS = "Removed remark from Person: %1$s";

    private final Index index;
    private final Remark remark;


    /**
     * @param index  of the person in the filtered person list to edit the remark
     * @param remark of the person to be updated to
     */
    public RemarkCommand(Index index, Remark remark) ``{``
        requireAllNonNull(index, remark);

        this.index = index;
        this.remark = remark;
    ``}``

    @Override
    public CommandResult execute(Model model) throws CommandException ``{``
        List&lt;Person> lastShownList = model.getFilteredPersonList();
        if (index.getZeroBased() >= lastShownList.size()) ``{``
            throw new CommandException(Messages.MESSAGE_INVALID_PERSON_DISPLAYED_INDEX);
        ``}``
        Person personToEdit = lastShownList.get(index.getZeroBased());
        Person editedPerson = new Person(
                personToEdit.getName(), personToEdit.getPhone(), personToEdit.getEmail(),
                personToEdit.getAddress(), personToEdit.getTags(),remark);

        model.setPerson(personToEdit, editedPerson);
        model.updateFilteredPersonList(Model.PREDICATE_SHOW_ALL_PERSONS);
        return new CommandResult(generateSuccessMessage(editedPerson));
    ``}``

    /**
     * Creates and returns a new Person whose remark field is updated.
     */
    private Person createEditedPerson(Person personToEdit, Remark remark) ``{``
        return new Person(personToEdit.getName(),
                personToEdit.getPhone(),
                personToEdit.getEmail(),
                personToEdit.getAddress(),
                personToEdit.getTags(),
                remark);
    ``}``

    /**
     * Generates a command execution success message based on whether
     * the remark is added to or removed from
     * ``{``@code personToEdit``}``.
     */
    private String generateSuccessMessage(Person personToEdit) ``{``
        String message = !remark.value.isEmpty() ? MESSAGE_ADD_REMARK_SUCCESS : MESSAGE_DELETE_REMARK_SUCCESS;
        return String.format(message, Messages.format(personToEdit));
    ``}``
    @Override
    public boolean equals(Object other) ``{``
        if (other == this) ``{``
            return true;
        ``}``

        // instanceof handles nulls
        if (!(other instanceof RemarkCommand)) ``{``
            return false;
        ``}``

        RemarkCommand e = (RemarkCommand) other;
        return index.equals(e.index)
                && remark.equals(e.remark);
    ``}``
``}``




'
</panel>

A "do within" task is useful if I want to set a deadline task with not only a due date but a starting date. For example, I am tasked to develop a new feature on an existing app, however access to the codebase will only be granted to me next Tuesday. In other words, I cannot begin working on this task _immediately_. An `Event` task implies I will be busy with the that task during the specified "from" and "to" date times, whereas a "do within" task implies more flexibility.

@kumar2215 I notice your approach indeed closes the app window, however the app continues to run in the background. This is evident from Gradle (`./gradlew run`) not exiting even when the window is closed. Instead, my approach does the following:

1. Instantiate a `ScheduledExecutorService` in `Application` child class
2. Inject the instance to the main controller (similar to injecting `Duke` in the JavaFX [tutorial](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/javaFxPart4.html#refactor-duke-to-use-fxml)
3. Schedule a one second delay before calling `Platform.exit()`
4. Override `stop()` in the `Application` child class to call `shutdown()` on the `ScheduledExecutorService`

More details can be found [here](https://github.com/zuoshihua/ip/commit/d23d13fdd652ed7606f0c57936ae34c7ac5dba37)
</panel>

For Mac/Linux users, check out [xdotool](https://github.com/jordansissel/xdotool)

Installation guide from the [README](https://github.com/jordansissel/xdotool/blob/master/README.md) copied below ðŸ‘‡

You may find xdotool in your distribution packaging:

* Debian and Ubuntu: `apt-get install xdotool`
* Fedora: `dnf install xdotool`
* FreeBSD: `pkg install xdotool`
* macOS: `brew install xdotool` or `sudo port install xdotool`
* OpenSUSE: `zypper install xdotool`

> [!NOTE]
> For Linux users, this tool only works with X11 sessions. Ensure you have X11 session installed for your desktop environment. If you're on Wayland, logout then login with X11.

Here's a script to automate the process

'''bash
xdotool search --name "$1" windowactivate
xdotool key "KP_Tab"

while read -r LINE
do
  xdotool type "$LINE"
  xdotool key "KP_Enter"
done &lt; "$2"
'''

To use it, copy the above to a file `auto.sh`

Next, create a file (in the same directory) with all your commands separated by newlines e.g.

'''
help
list
'''

Name this text file `commands.txt`

Run the script like this `./auto.sh [title] commands.txt` where `title` refers to the title of the window, i.e. the string you passed into `stage.setTitle()` in your JavaFX application entrypoint

</panel>

OpenJDK does not ship with JavaFX anymore. This is why I stick to Azul FX JDK 17 as it comes with JavaFX.

1. Uninstall the existing OpenJDK
2. Download the deb package for JDK 17 from [here](https://www.azul.com/downloads/?os=ubuntu&architecture=x86-64-bit&package=jdk#zulu)
3. Run `sudo dpkg -i &lt;path-to-deb-file>` to install

Personally, as I start to write bigger programs I notice I lean more towards SLAP. SLAP actually makes it easier to read code compared to not using it, especially when the code base is huge. 

As for the example you've shown about the `exitIfNoarguments` and `exitIfUnacceptableFileName`, the functions does seem short but when new requirements are added in the future it makes it easier to add them in codes with SLAP used rather than without. SLAP just makes the code more scalable compared to not using it, at least from experience. SLAP also allows the method extracted to be used somewhere else for convenience and make the code more DRY.

So personally, I would still use SLAP even though the method or function is short. But in the end, it really is just preference.
</panel>

> [@Nova1729](https://github.com/Nova1729) Yes, if you merged the PR in your fork (or merged it locally and pushed to your fork) and then un-merged it locally, you need to do a force-push to overwrite the merge that is still there in the fork.
> 
> Do be careful in force-pushing though, as it overwrites history. Do be VERY careful in force-pushing to the team repo, as you could end up overwriting other team members' work. Force-pushing to your own individual fork of the team repo should be relatively less risky, as you will only be overwriting your own work.

```

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S2/forum/issues/5#issuecomment-2597035417" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**14 :fas-comment:**
</div>

There may be several versions of Git installed on your computer.

1. Git bundled with Sourcetree - only accessible within Sourcetree unless you add the directory to PATH.
   ![https://confluence.atlassian.com/sourcetreekb/using-embedded-git-or-system-git-in-sourcetree-785323587.html](https://confluence.atlassian.com/sourcetreekb/files/785323587/785323568/1/1444983727324/GitOption1.png) https://confluence.atlassian.com/sourcetreekb/using-embedded-git-or-system-git-in-sourcetree-785323587.html
2. Standalone Git for Windows - only accessible within Git Bash unless you choose this option during installation to add Git to PATH, or add the directory to PATH manually afterwards.
   ![https://phoenixnap.com/kb/how-to-install-git-windows](https://phoenixnap.com/kb/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/adjust-git-path-environment.png)
3. Git in WSL - to access your Documents folder, navigate to /mnt/c/Users/yourusername/Documents, or open cmd or PowerShell in your Documents folder and type wsl to enter WSL.
</panel>

Just gonna +1 on the suggestions here to use relative paths, instead of re-stating how to do it. Since the iP is being packaged as a `.jar` file anyways, it can be run from any location, even from portable drives - so there's no guarantee that your program will even stay on the _same_ computer from run-to-run. Much better to just include it with the rest of the project files.

That being said, if you _did_ want to put your data file in the OS equivalent of `%APPDATA%` on Windows, it's theoretically doable. You'd need to:

1. Get the name of the current OS with `System.getProperty("os.name")`.
2. Get the user's full home directory path with `System.getProperty("user.home")`.
3. Branch based on the OS you've detected:
  a. Windows: get the full path of `%APPDATA%` by doing `System.getenv("APPDATA")`, and creating a subdirectory with your app's name
  b. macOS: Append `/Library/Application Support/app-name` to the user's full home directory
  c. Linux: It's a giant mess with no real standards, but the latest convention is `$HOME/.config/app-name`, so similar to macOS, append `/.config/app-name` to the user's home directory.

It's a lot more hassle, not quite worth it in my opinion.
</panel>

> As far as I know, we can only read data from `.jar` file , but cannot write data into it. So I think the only way to store data is using OS `APPDATA`, am I right?

Nope, you can write to anywhere on the filesystem, so long as the user running the program has the required permissions to do so! This means that you can write your data to a file in a location specified _relative to where the user stored the program at_.

So, if the user stored it in `~/Downloads/appname.jar`, and you specified a relative path of `./data/foo.txt`, the program would read from and write to `~/Downloads/data/foo.txt`. And if they launched it from `~/Desktop/bar/baz/appname.jar`, the program would read from/write to `~/Desktop/bar/baz/data/foo.txt`.
</panel>

I've taken a peek at your code, and you're not really using relative paths in the right way:

'''java
// ip/src/main/java/duke/component/Storage.java
private final String READ_FILE_PATH = "../../../data/list.txt";
private final String WRITE_FILE_PATH = "../../../data/list.txt";
'''


Relative paths specify a path to take _starting at the directory where the executable is located_. So, if the user stored your `.jar` file in `~/Downloads/appname.jar`, and you specified a relative path of `./data/foo.txt`, the program would read from and write to `~/Downloads/data/foo.txt`. And if they stored it in `~/Desktop/bar/baz/appname.jar`, the program would read from/write to `~/Desktop/bar/baz/data/foo.txt`. Right now, you're specifying a relative path of `parent directory 3/parent directory 2/parent directory 1/data/list.txt`, which will completely break if, for example, the user stores your `.jar` file in `/home/zechary28`.

With a bit of code, you can then ensure that you're always creating a directory with a certain name, and writing a file to that directory. You're free to store the save file wherever you want - you can decide to have it in a fixed location, or have it in a location that's relative to the executable. I'd recommend the latter approach.
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**11 :fas-comment:**

I'm interpreting it like this:

`Event` tasks are items which occur _continuously, throughout_ the specified time duration. For example, "Event: Global Geopolitical Destruction Conference 2025 (sponsored by Palantir), from 6 Feb to 8 Feb". Marking this task as "done" thus only really makes sense _after 8 Feb_ (unless you leave the conference early).

Meanwhile, `DoWithin` tasks are items which occur _once_, but _anytime within_ the specified time duration. So, for example, "DoWithin: Hack the GGDC, between 6 Feb to 8 Feb". So, marking this task as "done" would make sense any time between 6 Feb and 8 Feb, but not any time other than that.

If you extend the functionality further, you could prevent `Event` tasks from being marked as done until their duration is completed, add location tagging info, add reminders, etc. Meanwhile, extended functionality for `DoWithin` tasks could be automatically marking as missed.
</panel>

[I spent entirely way too long doing this writeup on the wide range of models and LLM tools that I've tried, but hey, if y'all are interested in that, feel free to dive in.](https://github.com/itsvari/ip/blob/master/AI.md)

But the TL;DR: I've used a _lot_ of models and tools, and I think LLMs are best suited for rubber duck debugging/code review and writing boilerplate, and not as full-on replacements for writing code yourself. In my opinion, the best models as of mid-Feb 2025 are `Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking`, `Gemini 2.0 Pro`, and `Claude 3.5 Sonnet`. For tools and providers, I like [Zed](https://zed.dev/) for its features (especially prompt libraries), and [GitHub Copilot](https://github.com/features/copilot) for its generous rate limits. IntelliJ's AI features are half-baked, and using the web interfaces adds too much friction. Running LLMs locally isn't quite meeting my own (admittedly high) standards just yet, but YMMV.
</panel>

</panel>

If you're experiencing GUI clipping of elements as shown below, but only on certain smoke test or OS environment, ensure that you did not perform any `stage.setMaxHeight()` or in general any stage set height function in the Java files, and instead use the FXML to configure it.

I believe that is because Windows and MacOS calculates "height" differently from one another; MacOS might actually calculate "height" as the height of the entire window while Windows calculate it as the height of the content of the window instead. (Just a theory though)

<div slot="header">

**8. :fas-info-circle: Coding Standard for instance-level private final variable.**
</div>

Should an instance-level `private` and `final` variable be considered a constant variable? If so, does that mean we should use `SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE`?

Example:
'''java
public class DialogBox extends HBox ``{``
    private final Label TEXT;
    private final ImageView DISPLAY_PICTURE;

    // ...
``}``
'''

</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S2/forum/issues/167#issuecomment-2644719267" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**9 :fas-comment:**
</div>

Thanks everyone for your input!

From everyone's input, I've come up with the following stance for myself:

As @Jovin-Ang @codebreaker64 and @TheEnd-alr-taken mentioned, I agree that the use of `final` doesn't necessarily entail the immutability of a variable.
But I also agree with the insight @meloppeitreet provided regarding a **non-static** `final` variable being deemed as a constant variable.
As such, I believe a better response to the question we might want to consider would be that, a variable is deemed a **constant** if it is (bare minimum) a `final` **primitive** variable (in the context of Java), or more specifically, not a pointer (like an object or array).

With this interpretation, whether something is an instance-level variable (non-static) or class-level variable (static), can still be considered a constant variable given the above mentioned constraints.

Let me know what you guys think with this interpretation.
</panel>

</div>

Iâ€™m using FXML for my UI layout, it makes the structure more readable and keeps the UI separate from the logic, which I find quite convenient. However, Iâ€™ve noticed that some developers prefer to build their UI directly in Java code instead of using FXML.

I was wondering what are the key advantages and trade-offs between these two approaches? Are there situations where using pure Java code is actually better than FXML? Or is FXML generally the recommended way to go?

For example, instead of defining a button in FXML like this:
'''xml
&lt;Button text="Click Me" onAction="#handleClick"/>
'''

They might do it programmatically in Java like this:
'''java
Button button = new Button("Click Me");
button.setOnAction(e -&gt; handleClick());
root.getChildren().add(button);
'''

Just to clarify, for our team project, are we required to strictly use FXML for the UI layout, or is there some flexibility to program the UI entirely in Java code? Also, would it be acceptable to use JFoenix for Material Design components directly in Java code, or are there any guidelines or restrictions we should follow?

Hi, I encountered this error too, you could try adding a Launcher class that calls your main class instead, and adjust your build.gradle accordingly

I encountered this same issue before and this is what worked for me!

An example of how I did it is below: 
package duke;

import javafx.application.Application;

public class Launcher ``{``
    public static void main(String[] args) ``{``
        assert args != null : "Application arguments should not be null";
        Application.launch(Main.class, args);
    ``}``
``}``

For the first question, I believe you are correct. The key difference between a and b is that, in order to call `h.add(a)` (where `h` is an instance of `History` and `a` is an instance of either `ActionX` or `ActionY`), the caller needs to have a reference to `h`, but does not need to have a reference to `a`. Therefore, we are allowed not to store the instances of `ActionX` and `ActionY`, while we are forced to maintain the field for `History`.

This is a sort of behind-the-scenes story that we *assume*. FYI, we might assume other scenariosâ€”such as creating `h` inside the method and returning itâ€”but I suppose this is not a good idea, given the intended functionality of `History`.
</panel>

**4 :fas-comment:**
</div>

In runtest.bat there is the line ```java -classpath ..\bin Duke < input.txt > ACTUAL.TXT```. You can add more tests under it such as ```java -classpath ..\bin Duke < inputSave.txt > ACTUAL_SAVE.TXT```. Your inputSave.txt can just contain your list command.

You can perform comparison using ```FC ACTUAL_SAVE.TXT EXPECTED_SAVE.TXT```, where EXPECTED_SAVE.TXT contains the list of  tasks after your list command.

In case you need it, I had to undo a "fast-forward" merge previously (luckily I realized it right after the merge) and I did it with:

'''bash
git checkout master
git reset --hard HEAD~2 # to make "master" go back to 2 commits before the current commit, I think you can use hash too
git merge branch --no-ff # To merge properly
''' 

(source: [StackOverflow link](https://stackoverflow.com/a/14308631/6931684))

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S2/forum/issues/174#issuecomment-2645677456" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**3 :fas-comment:**
</div>

One advantage I can think of is future-proofing in case we add additional values to the enum.

In the context of our IP, perhaps one may keep all the possible commands in a `Command` enum and the `Parser` class will do a switch case to call different functions according to the `Command` enum.

If we add a new command in `Command` and forget to deal with it in `Parser`, having a `default: throw new CommandNotFoundException()` will let you know what went wrong rather than just being silent and doing nothing when the command is used.
</panel>

Smoke test carried out on KDE Neon 6.3 with JavaFX Runtime 17.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ea33fa34-d446-4fa6-aac0-bb4a6f982e39)

Functionality is mostly intact - but there are a few bugs to do with parsing and file handling. 

If a malformed event/deadline command is provided (for instance, event Attend Meeting /from 2025-02-22 /to 2025-02-23 1903), unhandled exceptions occur

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/86be12b3-fa1e-4103-83a6-12ed712d1bf4)

Unfortunately, these malformed commands are immediately saved to ./data/donk.txt, meaning that subsequent commands like list and sort stop working entirely. Reloading the application doesn't help as the application attempts to load the malformed tasks on startup, mandating that the file be cleared manually. 

The handling of a malformed task creation command is part of the minimal spec of Level-5. I would suggest finding a way to have these errors be caught and handled gracefully, with the cause of the error made clear to the user. 
</panel>

**1. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡VSCode checkstyle configuration tip**
</div>

For those using VSCode who want the "check as you type" thing rather than running `./gradlew checkstyleMain` every time, you might want to follow these steps:

Assuming you already downloaded and placed your `checkstyle.xml` and `suppression.xml` files into the directory `./config/checkstyle/` from [here](https://github.com/se-edu/addressbook-level3/tree/master/config/checkstyle),

1. Install **'Checkstyle for Java'** extension
2. Right-click your `checkstyle.xml` file, select 'Set the Checkstyle Configuration File'
3. Add the following into your `settings.json` file:

'''json
  "java.checkstyle.properties": ``{``
    "config_loc": "$``{``workspaceFolder``}``/config/checkstyle/"
  ``}``
''' 

That 3rd step about `config_loc` is especially important, without which you might face this errorâš :
'''json
``{`` "message":"unable to parse configuration stream",
  "cause":``{``"message":"com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.api.CheckstyleException: Property $``{``config_loc``}`` has not been set"``}``
``}``
'''

If anyone wishes to correct or add-on to these steps, please go ahead. Thanks!
</panel>

UPDATE: If you do not intend to create any functionality with ListCell on selection, you can disable ListView's selection handling using the following code:

`personListView.addEventFilter(MouseEvent.MOUSE_PRESSED, event -&gt; event.consume());`

Combining this with `personListView.setSelectionModel(null);` will completely disable selection from ListView while ensuring no NullPointerException will be printed out.

**Hi, I have a question: How can I dynamically find the file path for a resource in my Java project (e.g., `data/Duke.txt`), without hardcoding the full path or depending on the current working directory?**

I currently have the file path hardcoded in the source code like this: `Documents\Local Computer\CS2103T\Individual Project\ip\data\Duke.txt`. This works as long as the project stays in the same location. However, if I move the entire project to a different location, the hardcoded path breaks, and I need to manually update it, which is not ideal.

I have also tried using `System.getProperty("user.dir")` to dynamically get the current directory path, and then locate `Duke.txt` relative to it. Unfortunately, this approach also fails because the `user.dir` depends on the directory where the program is executed. This causes inconsistent behavior when the program is run from different locations.

Is there a reliable way to dynamically determine and access files (such as `data/Duke.txt`) based on the project structure, regardless of where the program is run from?

i think you can try changing the version.

You did mention that you used JDK 17 for the rest of your project! 

You can try running the following command to check the Java version Gradle is using in your project:
./gradlew --version

This will show the JVM version Gradle is using. Even if your systemâ€™s default Java version (java -version) shows Java 22, Gradle can still use Java 17 for your project.

Since you are using a Gradle toolchain, your project will be built using Java 17, regardless of the systemâ€™s Java version. This means when you run:

./gradlew clean shadowJar

your JAR file will be Java 17-compatible, even though your system Java is Java 22.

I am not very sure about this! But this is something I tried before. You can check what JDK version your gradle project is using before you try changing the default version of java

**Link to JAR file:** https://github.com/darHH/ip/releases/download/A-releaseFinal/dar.jar
**Which OS'es to test on:** Windows | Mac | Linux

**Guide for smoke testers:**

1. Copy the jar file to an empty folder and test it from there. This should surface issues with hard-coded file paths.
2. When running the jar file for smoke testing, instead of double-clicking the jar file, do the following: open a terminal -&gt; navigate to the jar location -&gt; run the java -jar "JAR_FILE_NAME" command.
3. Post screenshots from your smoke tests.
4. Mention which OS you used for testing.
Thank you all in advance!

@samuelneo, I essentially went down the same path as you before discovering this post, and can confirm the following.

1. Checkstyle does not distinguish between normal and lambda style expression, [the setting is simply `caseIndent`](https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/checks/misc/indentation.html).
2. Faced similar issues when I tried regex and I cannot find any _complete_ solution.
3. The whole "[check format](https://checkstyle.sourceforge.io/filters/suppressioncommentfilter.html#Properties)", which is basically the rule, needs to be suppressed, and so, it is not possible to only suppress `caseIndent`.

So, I have decided to ignore this check via code comments. The rule name is `Indentation`. This works in Intellij with checkstyle-IDEA plugin, so the errors in Intellij disappear once I type these comments. In my case, it looks like the following:

```
// CHECKSTYLE.OFF: Indentation
return switch (op) ``{``
    case BYE -&gt; parseByeCommand(args);
    case HELP -&gt; parseHelpCommand(args);
    case LIST -&gt; parseListCommand(args);
    ...
``}``;
// CHECKSTYLE.ON: Indentation
```
</panel>

**2 :fas-comment:**
</div>


If you pushed the commit already

 **Rebase the last commit**:
   '''sh
   git rebase -i HEAD~N
   '''
   Replace `N` with the number of commits you want to modify.

In the rebase editor, change `pick` to `reword` for the commit you want to edit, then save and exit.

Modify the commit message when prompted, then save.

Force push the changes:
   '''sh
   git push --force
   '''

However, be careful with `--force`, because it rewrites the history and can cause issues if there are other people using your repo(diverging histories)

If you are still not sure, you can consult [here](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/committing-changes-to-your-project/creating-and-editing-commits/changing-a-commit-message)
</panel>

- Your `TaskList.mark()` method is expecting a `Task` object, but it is receiving a `String` instead.
- This could mean that the way your program is parsing and storing tasks is incorrect.
- The `execute()` method in `BasicCommand` is trying to mark a task as done but is mistakenly handling a `String` instead of a `Task`.

Look at `TaskList.java:56`, where the error occurs. It likely contains something like:

'''java
public void mark(int index) ``{``
    Task task = (Task) tasks.get(index); // Potential issue
    task.markAsDone();
``}``

'''

- Make sure `tasks.get(index)` actually returns a `Task`, not a `String`.
- If `tasks` is an `ArrayList&lt;String>`, that would explain the issue.
- `tasks` should be an `ArrayList&lt;Task>`.

âœ… **Fix:** Ensure `tasks` is correctly declared:

'''java
private ArrayList&lt;Task> tasks;

'''

If `tasks` contains `String`s instead, you may need to parse them into `Task` objects before storing them.

Look at how commands are being processed. If the `mark` command is treating task descriptions as `String` instead of `Task`, update it.

Example of a wrong approach:

'''java
public static Command parse(String input) ``{``
    if (input.startsWith("mark")) ``{``
        return new BasicCommand(input.substring(5)); // Wrong if input is stored as a String
    ``}``
``}``

'''

âœ… **Fix:** Ensure the index is parsed properly:

'''java
public static Command parse(String input) ``{``
    if (input.startsWith("mark")) ``{``
        int index = Integer.parseInt(input.substring(5)) - 1; // Adjusting for zero-based index
        return new BasicCommand(index);
    ``}``
``}``

'''

- Make sure `BasicCommand` correctly stores an `int` index, not a `String`.

Look at `BasicCommand.java:21`, where it crashes. It likely tries to mark a task as done.

'''java
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) ``{``
    tasks.mark((Task) taskIndex); // Wrong type
``}``

'''

âœ… **Fix:** Make sure `taskIndex` is an `int`, not a `Task`:

'''java
public void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage) ``{``
    tasks.mark(taskIndex); // Now taskIndex is an int, no casting needed
``}``

'''

<div slot="header">

**3 :fas-comment:**
</div>

To test the saving function that you implemented at Level-7, you need to ensure that your program correctly writes and reads data from the save file. 

Since your implementation should persist data across multiple runs, you need to test the program twice to verify that the saved data is correctly loaded.

- **First Run**: Provide an input that adds tasks and saves them.
- **Second Run**: Run the program again to check if the previously saved tasks are loaded correctly.

Your existing `runtest.bat` runs a single test using:

'''bat
java -classpath ..\bin Duke &lt; input.txt > ACTUAL.TXT

'''

You can modify it to run the test twice with different input files:

'''bat
REM First run: Adding tasks and saving them
java -classpath ..\bin Duke &lt; inputSave.txt > ACTUAL_SAVE.TXT

REM Second run: Checking if tasks are loaded correctly
java -classpath ..\bin Duke &lt; inputList.txt > ACTUAL_LOAD.TXT

REM Compare expected outputs
FC ACTUAL_SAVE.TXT EXPECTED_SAVE.TXT
FC ACTUAL_LOAD.TXT EXPECTED_LOAD.TXT

'''
- `inputSave.txt` should contain commands to add tasks.
- `inputList.txt` should contain a `list` command to check if tasks persist.
- `EXPECTED_SAVE.TXT` should contain the expected output after saving.
- `EXPECTED_LOAD.TXT` should contain the expected output after reloading.

To ensure a clean slate before running the test, you should delete any existing save file before the first test run. You can do this using:

'''bat
del data\duke.txt

'''
or within your Java test setup.

If you are using JUnit, implement a `@BeforeEach` method in `Test.java` to clear the save file before each test:

'''java
import org.junit.jupiter.api.BeforeEach;
import java.io.File;
import java.io.FileWriter;
import java.io.IOException;

public class DukeTest ``{``
    @BeforeEach
    void clearSaveFile() throws IOException ``{``
        File saveFile = new File("data/duke.txt");
        if (saveFile.exists()) ``{``
            new FileWriter(saveFile, false).close(); // Clears file contents
        ``}``
    ``}``
``}``

'''

Alternatively, you can implement a `clear` command in your bot that clears saved data and include it as the first command in `inputSave.txt`.

cells, handled by updateItem. This method is called pretty much anytime the
appearance of the ListView is changed, hence it's important to keep it thin
and not give that method too much work.

Your PersonCard constructor pulls quite a few images from resources. Can
you see if removing them and replacing them with simpler nodes like a Label
does the trick?

</panel>

Hii, as the others hv mentioned already: static constants should generally be declared inside a class or interface in Java. This is generally for encapsulation purposes.

I agree with @damithc that aggregation, composition, and multiplicity are labels used to describe an association.

From the textbook, aggregation is a weaker relationship than composition. In this case, determining whether the relationship is aggregation or composition depends on two key questions:
- Can the Square objects exist independently of the Board?
In other words, does the Board object not own the Square objects?
For example, if the Square objects can be reused elsewhere (e.g., as standalone objects for writing answers on exam papers), then the relationship is aggregation.
- Are the Square objects created and managed exclusively by the Board?
If the Square objects cannot exist without the Board and are tightly coupled to it, then the relationship is composition.

In my opinion, the relationship here is more likely composition because the Square objects are an integral part of the Board and do not make sense outside of it. The Board creates, manages, and owns the Square objects, which aligns with the definition of composition.

Hope this helps! :)
</panel>

'''java

        boolean isExit = false;

        while (!isExit) ``{``

I would think `Event`s are something that run `from` date `to` date, whereas these `LimitedTask`s are open `from` date `to` date. In implementation, maybe both of these types of tasks will be pushed to the top when running `list` to alert the user of important tasks in this current point of time. In terms of functionality, maybe 

- `Event` can only be marked as complete after `to`, 
- `LimitedTask` can only be marked after `from`, and might have additional alerts if it is still unmarked after `to`

Maybe they could both extend from the same class / interface, since both would have the `to` and `from` fields.

I think this is an interesting issue because it is technically due to a cosmetic issue that causes the use case to seem incorrect.

## Why it could be `severity.VeryLow`

- The formatting issue doesn't change the **functionality** or **logic content** of the use case itself.
- All intended information is still present, and a reader / developer who is familiar with use case structure can still **infer the intended meaning**.
- In that sense, it aligns with the definition of `severity.VeryLow`:  
  > "A flaw that is purely cosmetic and does not affect usage."

## Why it could also be seen as `severity.Low`

- Use cases are meant to clearly distinguish between **main flow**, **extensions**, and **exceptional conditions**.
- The incorrect formatting (e.g. â€œExtensionsâ€ embedded within step 4, and unclear indentation of 3a1) **blurs the logic hierarchy**.
- This could **confuse readers unfamiliar with the content**.
- That aligns with `severity.Low`:  
  > "A flaw that causes minor inconvenience and may affect interpretation."

## Final Thoughts

However, I think I lean towards  `severity.VeryLow` as we are familiar with the use case structure as developers. I think the question to ask is whether you could understand what was going on when reading this use case. If you could understand it but it was not cosmetically pleasing when reading it then I think  `severity.VeryLow` is the correct label.

But don't just base your answer to the team off my opinion and maybe wait for the other's perspectives too!

</panel>

Hi! So I believe the reason there is a dependency comes from this line [Sorry for the poor image quality]:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c2ad3c41-b338-476b-80cf-5ebe982826f1)

> why there is dependency between progressWatcher and activity?

From the underlined portion here, we can see when creating ```watchers``` in `Activity`, it actually does _depend_ on the static field `MAX` in `ProgressWatcher`. That's why there is a dependency here.

> is dependency redundant since progressWatcher implements Watcher and Watcher has association with Activity?

This isnt technically the official definition but I like to think of dependencies as weak associations because of that we can't really say the dependency is redundant as we have to capture the full associations of the class diagram i.e.  `Activity` needing `MAX` in `ProgressWatcher`. 

Hope this helps! (Sorry if any part seems unclear)

From the textbook:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a3d75ff1-7aff-4061-a5cb-36497c95bb80)

I assume that by "any number," you meant `*`. I believe we cannot assume the multiplicity to be `*` or `1` as the actual implementation may have a specific multiplicity.

For example, consider class A and class B such that class A has exactly two instances of B.

'''java
class A ``{``
    B b1;
    B b2;
``}``
'''

The following UML diagram is still correct, but assuming the multiplicity is `*` or `1` would be incorrect.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c7a72ff5-be5c-4d4c-a68b-f7e4690fe190)
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S2/forum/issues/191#issuecomment-2653614066" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**2 :fas-comment:**
</div>

I believe SLAP doesn't contradict the idea of avoiding deep nesting. While I don't think SLAP will help with reducing the number of layers of abstraction/nesting (the complexity of the code will still be present, hidden within separate methods), SLAP gives you the flexibility to exit the nesting once you've reached a level of abstraction that helps you understand how the code works.

In deeply nested code, you often need to read through each line and explore the innermost sections to understand it. However, with the SLAP approach, the code can be refactored into smaller methods at different abstraction levels, and well-named and well-documented methods at the higher levels will usually offer enough context to grasp the logic, saving you the effort of tracing the lower nested layers.
</panel>

</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S2/forum/issues/189" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**1. :fas-info-circle: ðŸ’¡[for WSL users] Dont run your project from IntelliJ using a windows path!**
</div>

I was wrestling with my iP and Gradle just not working for two days. Nothing worked, even building from terminal didn't work, the gradlew binary simply could not be run by bash despite chmod +x and other attempts.

Finally after two days I realised the issue - I had configured by project under intellij using the native windows path to WSL i.e. `\\wsl.localhost\Ubuntu-24.04\home\...` , so any files or binaries that intellij had been producing were produced as windows files, with the `\r` carriage return. After running `dos2unix` on my entire iP directory, things were fixed!

I realised I should have run IntelliJ in "remote mode" (exactly how VSCode does it), where it sets up a server on the remote machine, in this case WSL (there is a separate selection for this), and uses a client-server model to function instead. Interestingly, IntelliJ's remote mode is buggy and slow, while VSCode's one is basically flawless - I would have expected more out of a tool that costs so much but oh well that's two days wasted
</panel>

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/60faf11a-7375-4b70-ae8b-024d19d9bb45)

According to how the course website arranges the topics, I see association as a general, umbrella term that includes both aggregation and composition. Association is the _fundamental relationship_, while aggregation/composition are _specialized forms_ of it, adding extra constraints to specify ownership and lifecycle rules. 

To answer your first question - yes, it can be considered to be either aggregation or composition (but not both) as you are stating a more specific association. However, to determine which of the 2 will be based on how you see the question. Personally, I think they are a _"whole-part" relationship_ as the `Square`s would not exist without a `Board` holding them together. So in this scenario, I would incline more towards composition than aggregation.

Moving on to your second question. I agree with @damithc that association cannot be replaced entirely because then, we would be seeing association and aggregation/composition as 2 totally different concepts when they are in fact "superclass/subclass" of each other.

Hope this helps!
</panel>

> > Hi prof [@damithc](https://github.com/damithc)
> > 
> > 1. I have a question regarding the composition from `Handout` to `Section`. Why is it a `composition`?
> > 2. Also should `Brochure` to `Handout` be a composition too since a `cover page` would not exist `without` the `brochure `and it is a `part of the brochure`?
> > 3. Can the association from `Brochure` to `Handout` be bidirectional instead of two association lines?
> 
>     1. Because the question mentioned that "A Handout object **_composed_** of at least 2 and no more than 5 Section objects".
> 
>     2. It is part of the brochure, yes. But I believe that without a brochure, a cover page can still exist (i.e. it may become a normal page, in real life).
> 
>     3. The answer should be yes. I don't see any reason to compulsorily show two separate lines.


The behaviour suggests that Handout A can reference to Brochure A, which can have the cover Handout A, and to Brochure B, which can have the cover Handout B. If the arrow is bidirectional this means Brochure B must have the cover Handout A if Handout A can reference Brochure B, which does not match the intended behaviour. So it's best to draw it as 2 unidirectional arrows

</panel>

To add on, antiviruses sometimes raise false-positives on programs you're working on (especially if they involve I/O or system calls). 

If the antivirus has already acted you should be able to recover the affected file from quarantine through the antivirus application, after which you can add the project folder as an exclusion to prevent further misdetections. Every antivirus has a different interface so its best to consult the respective guides on how to do so. For example, [this is the guide for Norton](https://support.norton.com/sp/en/us/home/current/solutions/v3672136).
</panel>

<panel  popup-url="https://github.com/nus-cs2103-AY2425S2/forum/issues/191#issuecomment-2655561653" expanded>
<div slot="header">

**2 :fas-comment:**
</div>

To add on to what was discussed, Deep-Nesting and Abstraction are not similar in one key aspect: Deep-nesting by definition recursively inherits scope. This means at a certain point/LoC there can be many different variables or calculations happening in context that makes reasoning about code behavior and thus debugging difficult. A related paradigm for classes is the [Single Responsibility Principle](https://nus-cs2103-ay2425s2.github.io/website/se-book-adapted/chapters/principles.html#single-responsibility-principle).

Furthermore, when using an IDE like Intellij IDEA, the navigation between functions is handled very elegantly â€” especially for runtime debugging. Combined with the significant benefits of Abstraction for codebase maintainability, there is a very strong motivation to use Abstraction wherever applicable.
</panel>

</panel>

I agree with @Jovin-Ang and @codebreaker64 . A private final instance variable is not a constant in the same sense as a static final variable. The final keyword only ensures the reference cannot be reassigned, but it does not guarantee immutability. If the object itself is mutable, its state can still change. Since these variables are instance-specific and not shared across all instances, they should follow lowerCamelCase, while SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE should be reserved for static final constants
</panel>

<div slot="header">

**1 :fas-comment:**
</div>

I agree with Prof @damithc that as association cannot be _replaced_ by aggregation or composition.

As for whether to _add_ aggregation or composition, I guess it depends on the context.

If the `Board` and `Square` classes are part of a chess game, for example, then we can see that a `Board` cannot exist without multiple `Squares`, and so we can represent the _whole-part_ relationship by adding ___composition___ (__solid__ diamond) to the existing association.

If the `Board` represents just a plain board, and `Square` represents some square pieces, then this becomes a _container-containee_ relationship where the `Board` can still exist separately without any `Square`s. We can represent this relationship by adding ___aggregation___ (_unfilled_ diamond) to the existing associatoin.

This is based on my understanding. I could be mistaken here.

References:
- https://nus-cs2103-ay2425s2.github.io/website/schedule/week4/topics.html#design-modelling-modelling-structure-class-diagrams-basic
- https://nus-cs2103-ay2425s2.github.io/website/schedule/week4/topics.html#design-modelling-modelling-structure-class-diagrams-basic

**1 :fas-comment:**
</div>

**editing most recent commit**
- make sure you are in the correct branch and run this command `git commit --amend -m "new commit message..."`
- then run `git push --force-with-lease &lt;repository> &lt;branch>`

**editing older commits**
- run `git rebase -i HEAD~&lt;N>` N being number of commits to jump back
- editor will show up 
- change pick to reword (or edit) on the commit you want to modify
- edit the commit message and close the editor
- run `git rebase --continue`
- run `git push --force`

note: be careful when using `--force`, check out this [thread](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8981194/changing-git-commit-message-after-push-given-that-no-one-pulled-from-remote)
</panel>

</panel>

**1 :fas-comment:**
</div>

this is because the gradle provided by the module is not compatible with JDK21.
I think you need to check whether you have downloaded JDK17 or not first.
If you have downloaded, then you need to reconfigure your environment variable, change java home to the current address of your JDK17.
If you haven't download that, then download JDK17 first and do as above.
To check whether you have done, open a command line (powershell...) and input java --version to see if it's like:
java 17.0.14 2025-01-21 LTS
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 17.0.14+8-LTS-191)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 17.0.14+8-LTS-191, mixed mode, sharing)
and then go to your intelij to reset your project's java version at the same time.
</panel>

</panel>
